description:
Pyronema omphalodes is a species of ascomycete fungus that belongs to the Pyronemataceae family. It is a saprophytic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter in the environment.

Pyronema omphalodes is known for its distinctive cup-shaped fruiting bodies, which can range in color from yellow to orange or red. These fruiting bodies, also called apothecia, are typically small, measuring around 2-10 mm in diameter.

The fungus reproduces sexually through the production of ascospores, which are formed within specialized structures called asci. The ascospores are released from the asci and can be dispersed by wind or water to colonize new substrates.

Pyronema omphalodes is commonly found growing on burnt or charred wood, soil, and other decaying plant material, particularly in areas that have been recently exposed to fire or other disturbances. It plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter and the recycling of nutrients in its natural ecosystems.

This species is of particular interest to mycologists and ecologists due to its adaptations to thrive in post-fire environments and its potential role in the recovery of ecosystems after a fire event.
